Generation I.Red: It stores electric energy under very high pressure. It often explodes with little or no provocation.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: It stores electric energy under very high pressure. It often explodes with little or no provocation.
Generation I.Yellow: Stores electrical energy inside its body. Even the slightest shock could trigger a huge explosion.
Generation I.Stadium: Stores enormous amounts of electricity within its body and explodes with the slightest provocation. Extremely dangerous.

Generation II.Gold: It is dangerous. If it has too much electricity and has nothing to do, it amuses itself by exploding.
Generation II.Silver: It stores an overflowing amount of electric energy inside its body. Even a small shock makes it explode.
Generation II.Crystal: The more energy it charges up, the faster it gets. But this also makes it more likely to explode.
Generation II.Stadium 2: It is dangerous. If it has too much electricity and has nothing to do, it amuses itself by exploding. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) It stores an overflowing amount of electric energy inside its body. Even a small shock makes it explode. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Electrode eats electricity in the atmosphere. On days when lightning strikes, you can see this Pok é mon exploding all over the place from eating too much electricity.
Generation III.Sapphire: One of Electrode 's characteristics is its attraction to electricity. It is a problematical Pok é mon that congregates mostly at electrical power plants to feed on electricity that has just been generated.
Generation III.Emerald: They appear in great numbers at electric power plants. Because they feed on electricity, they cause massive and chaotic blackouts in nearby cities.
Generation III.FireRed: It explodes in response to even minor stimuli. It is feared, with the nickname of “The Bomb Ball.”
Generation III.LeafGreen: It stores electric energy under very high pressure. It often explodes with little or no provocation.

Generation IV.Diamond: It is known to drift on winds if it is bloated to bursting with stored electricity.

Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: The tissue on the surface of its body is curiously similar in composition to an Apricorn . When irritated, this Pokémon lets loose an electric current equal to 20 lightning bolts.

Generation IX.Scarlet: The more energy it charges up, the faster it gets. But this also makes it more likely to explode.
Generation IX.Violet: It explodes in response to even minor stimuli. It is feared, with the nickname of the Bomb Ball.
